image.title: DW.COM
image.description: News, Analysis and Service from Germany and Europe - in 30 Languages

item.title: Scholz: Ukraine won't accept Russian dictatorship
item.description: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz says he strongly believes Russia won't win its war in Ukraine. His remarks come as the conflict overshadows commemorations to mark the end of World War II in Europe.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Wolfsburg reclaim Women's Bundesliga in some style
item.description: Bayern Munich wrestled the title from Wolfsburg last season, but the perennial women's Bundesliga champions have reclaimed it after a 10-1 win. Elsewhere Frankfurt are in good shape for Europe and Chelsea won the WSL.
item.dc:subject: NRS-Import

item.title: Germany: CDU set to win Schleswig-Holstein state election
item.description: The conservative CDU is on track for victory in the northern state of Schleswig-Holstein, forecasts from broadcasters ARD and ZDF show. The poll was seen as a test of Chancellor Olaf Scholz's response to the Ukraine war.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Syria's Bashar Assad pays rare visit to ally Iran
item.description: Syrian President Bashar Assad has visited Iran for only the second time since the civil war broke out in his country. The two nations are united by their enmity toward Israel.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: EU citizens are full of hope for the future of Europe
item.description: A select group of citizens of the EU has gathered multiple times since last May to discuss what the bloc should look like in the years ahead. But implementing some of the ideas would mean overhauling how the EU works.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: How Schalke 'reinvented' themselves to get back to the Bundesliga
item.description: One year ago, Schalke were relegated in a cloud of internal chaos and on the brink of insolvency. Twelve months later, the Royal Blues are back in the Bundesliga and on the long road to financial recovery.
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: Israel: 2 Palestinian suspects in Elad attack arrested
item.description: Israeli security forces say they have arrested two Palestinians suspected of carrying out a deadly attack in the town of Elad last week. The detentions come after a massive manhunt.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Ukraine war puts spotlight on Red Cross service to find missing people
item.description: Wars and natural disasters tear families apart worldwide. The German Red Cross tries to put them back in touch.
item.dc:subject: Germany

item.title: Nepal: Sherpa Kami Rita breaks own Everest record
item.description: The Nepalese Sherpa guide Kami Rita has scaled Mount Everest for the 26th time, setting a new world record. More than 300 people have died trying to conquer the world's highest peak.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Ukraine: G7 to impose fresh sanctions on Russia — live updates
item.description: After talks with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, leaders of the G7 nations pledged further economic isolation of Russia and vowed "phasing out or banning" Russian oil imports. Follow DW for the latest.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Europe's first samurai museum opens in Berlin
item.description: As a new museum on the samurai opens in Berlin, here are five facts about how the legendary warriors and political elite shaped the history of Japan for centuries
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Hong Kong: Ex-security chief John Lee named new leader
item.description: An election committee composed largely of pro-Beijing figures voted for John Lee, a former security official, to be the new leader of Hong Kong. Lee, the only candidate in the vote, replaces Carrie Lam in July.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Benjamin Rich: British YouTuber denies reports of being arrested in Kazakhstan
item.description: Benjamin Rich, a British national known for his YouTube travel blog, shot back at Russia's claim that he was arrested at the Baikonur Cosmodrome spaceport. Rich said he was only questioned for a few hours by authorities.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Germany: Police investigate device found at Russian news agency in Berlin
item.description: A device that was discovered Friday in the basement of Ria Novosti's office in Berlin's Steglitz district was "probably incendiary," according to police. An investigation into the "dangerous object" is still ongoing.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Brazil: Lula launches presidential bid to overcome 'criminal' Bolsonaro
item.description: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva said he wanted to "send fascism back to the sewer of history" at a rally in Sao Paulo. He served as the 35th president of Brazil from 2003 to 2010.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: What Sinn Fein's win could mean for Northern Ireland, UK
item.description: For the first time, a nationalist party has become the strongest party in the Northern Ireland Assembly. What does Sinn Fein stand for? And what could this result mean for the future?
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Northern Ireland: Sinn Fein secures historic election win
item.description: The Irish nationalist party Sinn Fein vowed a "new era" as it won the most seats in the Assembly for the first time — a victory that could bring the party's ultimate goal of a united Ireland a step closer.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Bayer Leverkusen strategy pays off with Champions League return
item.description: Bayer Leverkusen will return to the Champions League next season after a three-year absence. They got over the line with a typically topsy-turvy win that highlighted the long-term strategy the club has employed.
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: Mysterious series of deaths among Russian oligarchs
item.description: Seven Russian oligarchs, many involved with oil and gas, have recently died under mysterious circumstances. Though suicide is officially suspected, speculation about the Kremlin's involvement abounds.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Bundesliga: Arminia Bielefeld on the brink
item.description: Arminia Bielefeld waited 11 years to return to the Bundesliga, but their two-season stay in the top flight seems set to end after defeat by Bochum. Arminia, one of Germany's yo-yo clubs, will no doubt be back for more.
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: Victory Day in Europe: Ukraine war puts spotlight on Russia
item.description: VE-Day marks Nazi Germany's unconditional surrender in WW2. Russia celebrates it on May 9 and many fear Vladimir Putin may use the opportunity to mobilize his country for all out war.
item.dc:subject: Germany

item.title: Borussia Dortmund cancel Israel trip after concerns raised
item.description: The post-season trip has been called off after members of Borussia Dortmund's team raised concerns due to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The Bundesliga runners-up were due to play a friendly against Maccabi Netanya.
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: Watching Karl Lagerfeld's estate go under the hammer
item.description: On the day Diego Maradona's football jersey fetched a record sum at Sotheby's London, DW's Brenda Haas went to the auction house's Cologne branch to watch her first auction.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: COVID-19: Pandemic trends in three charts
item.description: Only a few countries are reporting more new coronavirus infections compared with the previous two weeks. DW sums up the global data on the current situation in three charts.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: Eintracht Frankfurt daring to believe in Europa League dream
item.description: Eintracht Frankfurt’s win over West Ham in the Europa League semifinals secured them a place in a first major final for 42 years. It’s about time this football club was introduced back to the continent’s biggest stage.
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: Germany's Fuggerei: The world's oldest social housing project
item.description: Five hundred years after the Fuggerei estate was opened in Augsburg, the rents remain under €1, and diverse people facing financial hardship still have housing security.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Domenico Tedesco left to pick up the pieces following RB Leipzig's latest low
item.description: RB Leipzig's Europa League campaign crashed in Glasgow as Rangers won 3-1 to book their ticket to the final in Seville. For Leipzig coach Domenico Tedesco, it was another night to forget in a season going south.
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: Western companies leave Russia — taking Russian jobs with them
item.description: More and more Russians are losing their jobs due to Western sanctions on Russia, and some are having to painfully rethink their future. With some sanctions' effects yet to be felt, the number of unemployed could grow.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Think 8 hours of sleep is best? Think again!
item.description: Are you 38 or older? Then you may want to rethink how much sleep you truly need. A team of international researchers has found that less is more.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: 5 things we can learn from Marlene Dietrich
item.description: Marlene Dietrich died on May 6, 1992 — 30 years ago. She fled the Nazis and conquered Hollywood. She remains a role model in times of crisis.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Ukraine: How farm vehicles stolen by Russia were remotely disabled
item.description: Russian soldiers looted combine harvesters and tractors worth millions of dollars from Ukraine, according to a media report. But the machinery was deactivated remotely before it could be put to use.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: Bitcoin boom spikes amid perceived risks
item.description: Central African Republic and El Salvador have made Bitcoin legal tender and Panama has approved a bill to regulate crypto assets. Experts warn that nations that adopt crypto currencies risk instability.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Documenta cancels talks amid antisemitism row
item.description: The 2022 edition of the world-famous contemporary art show has suddenly axed discussions on the topic of artistic freedom, which had planned to address accusations of antisemitism.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: New German open letter: 'Yes' to weapons for Ukraine
item.description: Pianist Igor Levit, Nobel laureate Herta Müller and 55 other intellectuals have sent an appeal to Chancellor Olaf Scholz. They say Germany should supply heavy weapons to Ukraine.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Germany plans documentation center on Nazi occupation in Europe
item.description: Almost 80 years after the end of the Second World War, the German government has approved a concept for a documentation center in Berlin. Its focus: the effects of the Nazi era in Europe.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: What are millets and can they help create global food security?
item.description: The Russian invasion of Ukraine has pushed food insecurity onto the table. Could an overlooked cereal help steady the situation and feed the global population in an era of climate crisis?
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: 'Navalny' documentary hits theaters in Germany
item.description: Being an outspoken enemy of the Kremlin nearly cost Alexei Navalny his life. In this documentary that feels like a spy thriller, Putin's rival uncovers the facts about his poisoning.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Ukraine: How drones are changing the way of war
item.description: The war in Ukraine shows that unmanned aerial vehicles are part of modern warfare. Drones have various tasks from aerial surveillance to missile defense.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: German Overshoot Day: 'We cannot continue like this'
item.description: Germany has used more resources in the first third of 2022 than are sustainably available to it for an entire year. Here's what needs to change.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: DW documentary 'Guardians of Truth' premieres in Berlin
item.description: Turkish journalist Can Dündar and Mexican investigative journalist Anabel Hernandez both live in exile. They share their stories in a new documentary and at the Berlin premiere.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: COVID: Omicron subvariants 'escaping the previous immunity'
item.description: You may be at risk of catching the new subvariants BA.4 or BA.5 even if you had the original omicron, virologist Alex Sigal told DW's Science Unscripted.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: Open letter about weapons deliveries to Ukraine draws criticism
item.description: The publication of an open letter to German Chancellor Scholz signed by leading cultural figures has triggered a fierce debate about the planned delivery of heavy weapons to Ukraine — especially on social media.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Can Algeria contribute to the EU's energy security?
item.description: Timely decisions, long-term commitments and a broader vision could help the European Union increase ties with the Western Mediterranean. Algeria, with its large reserves, could enhance the bloc's energy security.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: DOK.fest Munich puts spotlight on Ukraine
item.description: After a two-year break due to the pandemic, the documentary film festival is once again held in cinemas. A political thriller about Alexei Navalny opens the event.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Will buying cars online really take off?
item.description: Boosted by the popularity of electric automaker Tesla, more people than ever are buying vehicles online. UBS estimates the web will make up half of all car sales by 2030, but what will that mean for traditional dealers?
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: Breed accounts for less than 10% of a dog's behavior
item.description: If you're looking for a dog with a specific personality, its breed will tell you less than the environment in which it is raised, a new study suggests.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: Will an EU oil embargo put the lights out at Schwedt's refinery?
item.description: As EU member states push for a Russian oil embargo, Germany's PCK Schwedt refinery is facing an uncertain future. It runs wholly on Russian imports, and many locals aren't so sure alternatives can be found in time.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: Carbon farming: Climate change solution or greenwashing?
item.description: European agriculture produces millions of tons of CO2 every year. Could encouraging farmers to capture carbon on their land to sell credits to businesses help reduce emissions?
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Germans split over heavy weapons deliveries to Ukraine
item.description: The German public is divided on the issue of military support for Ukraine. Many fear the delivery of tanks and training of Ukrainian soldiers in Germany may drag the country into the war.
item.dc:subject: Germany

item.title: Is India facing a post-pandemic employment crisis?
item.description: India's job market is tightening, and skilled workers are finding it harder to enter the workforce. Government job drives and the informal economy have been unable to make up the difference.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Record-breaking heat waves show we need to adapt to the climate crisis now
item.description: India is just the latest country to face life-threatening temperatures before summer has even started. As extreme heat becomes more frequent around the world, how can affected areas adapt to remain livable?
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Europe cooperates on gas, as Russia turns off taps to Poland and Bulgaria
item.description: Russia has halted gas exports to Poland and Bulgaria, ramping up the pressure on all EU states to find alternative suppliers. Some are working on cutting Russian gas altogether, others have plans to share with neighbors.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Russia posts trained dolphins at Black Sea naval base, satellite images show
item.description: Dolphin pens were moved to the Black Sea naval base around the time Russia invaded Ukraine, according to the US Naval Institute's analysis of satellite imagery.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: Origin of hepatitis outbreak in kids is still unknown
item.description: Doctors are puzzled by an unknown strain of hepatitis presenting in children, which has in some cases caused liver failure. But they are learning more. Symptoms are like jaundice.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: Elvira Nabiullina: The central banker Vladimir Putin is relying on to clean up Russia's economic mess
item.description: Elvira Nabiullina has charmed many in the West with her policymaking — and clothing choices. Analysts say she has blemished her reputation by remaining at the helm to help sustain Putin's war machine in Ukraine.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: About a million people live near dangerous dams in Brazil
item.description: Data analysis by DW reveals many Brazilians live near dams that, without proper maintenance and governmental oversight, could be deadly in the case of failure.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Cashing in: No payment problems for Russian tourists in Turkey
item.description: Turkey is trying to attract more Russian tourists by expanding the usage of the Russian Mir payment system in the country, as it seeks to bypass payment bottleneck created by Western sanctions.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Putin and Parkinson's: What experts say about his health
item.description: A video released by the Kremlin last weekend shows Putin in seemingly bad health. Some commentators and tabloids claim he has Parkinson's. What do doctors think?
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: Swiping right on climate love: Dating apps and environmental advocacy
item.description: Dating platforms have noticed their users are hot for climate issues and are incorporating features to help them connect with each other. But how useful are additions like OkCupid's climate advocate badge?
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Germany top buyer of Russian energy since Ukraine invasion began: report
item.description: Russian fossil fuel exports are undermining sanctions imposed on the Kremlin over its invasion of Ukraine, a study says. Germany and the EU remain the biggest buyers of Russian energy.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Mars probe discovers 'shocking' new aurora
item.description: The Emirates Mars Mission says it's a first: They have spotted a worm-like aurora that stretches halfway round Mars. It looks like our northern lights.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: Turning the tide on land degradation
item.description: Human activity has led to widespread land degradation and put our very survival as a species at risk. But by reversing course, we can tackle climate change and biodiversity loss — and make a better life for billions.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Warsaw and Budapest split over Russian energy ties
item.description: Poland and Hungary have shared a tilt towards the nationalist right, bound also by a mutual distrust of the EU. But their relations with Russia are anything but alike. DW explores the energy ties that bind — and don't.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: Elon Musk buys Twitter: What it means for the platform
item.description: Musk's vision of creating a bastion of free speech with less moderation and a higher bar for removing offending tweets could also lead to more abusive content, disinformation and hate speech, critics fear.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: Endometriosis: The long wait for a diagnosis
item.description: Sabrina Lobing waited more than a decade for a diagnosis that explained her symptoms. Now she knows she has endometriosis — a disease that little is known about and yet is very common.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: Scientists sound alarm bells on noise pollution
item.description: The rumble of road traffic and trains, the bustle of the bar downstairs or the roar of a plane taking off – noise is a problem that is increasingly hurting health and disrupting ecosystems.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Beyond ecology: The trees at the heart of our culture
item.description: From Ireland to the Amazon to Kenya, trees can hold traditional or even sacred value. DW takes a look at trees and forests of cultural importance to communities around the world. Some are under threat.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Shanghai COVID lockdown threatens new export delays
item.description: Nearly a third of goods leaving the Port of Shanghai are held up due to a strict COVID lockdown. The delays are set to exacerbate a supply chain crisis that has caused shortages and price rises across the world.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: Let's talk about salt — how unhealthy is it really?
item.description: Most people consume too much salt — with potentially massive effects for their health. But it's possible to find a healthy balance.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: So you want to live forever?
item.description: Spoiler: You probably won't be able to live forever, even if you want to. How about settling for a life free from age-related ailments like Alzheimer's or arthritis instead?
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: COVID: In a crowd of unmasked people, can a mask still protect you?
item.description: Many countries around the world are easing mask mandates. If no one else is masking up, should you?
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: From Mumbai to Paris, the cities investing in the planet
item.description: This Earth Day, we show how city councils and mayors have stepped up to boldly decarbonize in the face of national government inaction.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Climate crisis: How to cope with eco-anxiety
item.description: Does worrying about climate change keep you up at night? Growing numbers of people are struggling with eco-anxiety, or distress about the state of the planet. If you're one of them, these expert tips might help.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Glass windows kill billions of birds a year. Scientists are working to change that
item.description: Conservationists are trying to convince governments and building owners around the world to introduce changes to stop birds from flying into reflective glass. Experts say the solutions are surprisingly simple.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: The thriving gardens at the heart of Rio de Janeiro's favelas
item.description: In one of the most dangerous and deprived neighborhoods in the Brazilian city, residents are now finding hope and employment by growing fruit and vegetables.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: European Space Agency halts cooperation with Russia on moon missions
item.description: The European Space Agency's move marks the latest in the deterioration of space-based relations with Russia.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: New omicron variants: What we know so far
item.description: A new omicron subvariant, BA.2.12.1, is spreading in the US and India. German Health Minister Lauterbach has expressed concern about the highly contagious coronavirus variant. Here's what we know so far.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: China turns cities into sponges to stop flooding
item.description: In the coming decade, China is expanding its plans for sponge cities. They can help prevent flooding, promote biodiversity and cut emissions. But what exactly are these cities and how do they work?
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Germany: Over 1 in 4 people have 'migrant background'
item.description: The number of people with "migrant background" — foreigners and people with foreign roots — keeps rising in Germany, with Turkey, Poland and Russia the top three countries of familial origin.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Cities are major polluters: Can we make them climate neutral?
item.description: Spewing most of the world's heat-trapping gases, fast-growing cities need to be transformed into clean, low emissions ecosystems in the struggle against climate breakdown.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Astronaut Samantha Cristoforetti: ISS is a 'beacon of hope'
item.description: Ahead of the launch of her Minerva mission to the International Space Station, Cristoforetti talked about the cooperation among European, US and Russian crew members in light of the ongoing Russian invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:subject: Science
